pages.text:
All St. Augustine Events
The Oldest City is known for its unique and plentiful events.
As the longest European-occupied settlement in the United States, St. Augustine is recognized as the nation’s oldest city and the host of many major events. St. Augustine's annual celebrations reflect this rich heritage and culture, where visitors and locals convene on historic downtown's brick streets. Our
Calendar of Events
lists all the gathering—big and small—whether they're at the beach, downtown, or on the river. There are historic reenactments, festivals and fairs, live concerts, and pirate parties, too. There's so many events to experience in St. Augustine that locals say, "it's a small town with a
big
calendar."

Dark of the Moon Ghost Tour
Armed only with glowsticks, guides tell tales of history and ghosts.
Select Dark Nights | Times Vary
View Website
(904) 829-0745
Dark of the Moon Ghost Tour
(904) 829-0745
St. Augustine Lighthouse
100 Red Cox Road
St. Augustine, FL 32080
View Google Map
Share This
Well after dark, during certain phases of the moon, the St. Augustine Lighthouse opens for a special history and ghost tour featuring true stories about the people who lived, visited, and worked at the lighthouse.
The tales also include information about those who died on the grounds and the ghostly encounters that have happened. This is the only regular tour that welcomes you into the lighthouse grounds at night and includes a climb to the top. Along the way, the guide shares the lighthouse's history, relating true tales of a ghostly presence.
Warning, in addition to being spooky, these tours are popular — you are strongly encouraged to book the tour while trip planning, before arriving in town.
USA Today
readers have voted the St. Augustine Lighthouse as one of the top 10 best haunted destinations in the United States.
Admission:
$29.95 for all adults and youth, including seniors. $24.95 for children ages seven to 12. Children must be at least seven years old and at least 44 inches tall. They must be able to climb the lighthouse stairs on their own.
When:
The days and times change with the seasons. In the winter, tours are generally available Fridays - Sundays, with at least one 90-minute tour each evening. Tours may start as early as 7:30 and the last tour could start as late as 10:45. Check their calendar
for exact times and availability, and to purchase tickets.
Schedule for Planning:
In June and July, the tours are offered at 8:30 p.m. on Wednesdays through Sundays. There is no Dark of the Moon Tour on July 4.
During other months, the tours are offered on Fridays through Sundays, with the first tour starting as early as 7:30 p.m. on some days, and with the last tour starting as late as 10:15 p.m. on other days.
There is usually a Dark of the Moon Tour on Halloween, regardless of the day of the week.
In the winter, tours are held on Fridays through Sundays, with extra tours on some school vacation weeks, including the week between Christmas and New Year's Eve.
Where:
At the St. Augustine Lighthouse, 100 Red Cox Road, St. Augustine, Florida 32080
Important Information:
The dates and times are updated seasonally. Factors include the phase of the moon, daylight saving time, and sunset. Please use
this link to see when the tour is running and to book tickets.
Dark of the Moon Ghost Tour
(904) 829-0745
St. Augustine Lighthouse
100 Red Cox Road
St. Augustine, FL 32080

Farmers Market at the Classic Car Museum
Support local businesses and farmers at this community event.
Sundays | 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.
Farmers Market at the Classic Car Museum
4730 US 1 S.
St. Augustine, FL 32086
View Google Map
Share This
Every Sunday, from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m., the St. Augustine Farmers Market takes place at the Classic Car Museum. Hosted by The Little Green Kitchen, this community-based event brings new and exciting vibes to the south end of town.
The market has room for more than 100 vendors, with the focus on local small businesses and Florida-farmed produce. Shop for various goods such as handmade arts and crafts, skincare, artisan food, plants/flowers, sustainable living items, and other specialty finds.
The Classic Car Museum makes for a fun, family-friendly environment with ample room for activities. On-site parking is available.
Admission:
Free
When:
Every Sunday from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.
Where:
The
Classic Car Museum
, 4730 US Highway 1 South, St. Augustine, Florida 32086

Farmers Market at the Classic Car Museum
Support local businesses and farmers at this community event.
Sundays | 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.
Farmers Market at the Classic Car Museum
4730 US 1 S.
St. Augustine, FL 32086
View Google Map
Share This
Every Sunday, from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m., the St. Augustine Farmers Market takes place at the Classic Car Museum. Hosted by The Little Green Kitchen, this community-based event brings new and exciting vibes to the south end of town.
The market has room for more than 100 vendors, with the focus on local small businesses and Florida-farmed produce. Shop for various goods such as handmade arts and crafts, skincare, artisan food, plants/flowers, sustainable living items, and other specialty finds.
The Classic Car Museum makes for a fun, family-friendly environment with ample room for activities. On-site parking is available.
Admission:
Free
When:
Every Sunday from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.
Where:
The
Classic Car Museum
, 4730 US Highway 1 South, St. Augustine, Florida 32086

Supervillian 5K & 10K Race
Be a superhero for the homeless during this Nocatee race.
Sunday, Sep. 7, 2025 | 7:45 a.m.
Supervillian 5K & 10K Race
400 Nocatee Center Way
Ponte Vedra, FL 32081
View Google Map
Share This
The Road Runners Club of America presents Nocatee's Supervillian 5K and 10K races (formerly the Superhero 5K and 10K race) on Sunday, September 7, 2025, beginning at 7:45 a.m. Proceeds from the event go to St. Francis House of St. Augustine, a homeless shelter in St. Johns County.
The 10K race begins at 7:45 a.m., and the 5K race and one-mile fun run start at 8:00 a.m. All races begin at Nocatee Field station.
Each participant receives a chip-timed 5K or 10K running distance, a superhero race t-shirt (for the first 200 runners), a superhero race finisher medal, and a free, downloadable finisher photo.
Registration:
Register now
for $35.00 for the 10K, $35.00 for the 5K, and $20.00 for the one-mile fun run.
When:
The 10K race starts at 7:45 a.m., and the 5K and one-mile fun run start at 8:00 a.m. on September 7, 2025.
Where:
Nocatee Station Field at 400 Nocatee Center Way in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida 32081.
About St. Francis House of St. Augustine:
This residential program accommodates 16 men, 12 women, and four families. In addition to providing for the short-term needs of homeless individuals, St. Francis House helps individuals and families achieve stability, self-sufficiency, and a viable plan for their future.
Supervillian 5K & 10K Race
400 Nocatee Center Way
Ponte Vedra, FL 32081

Fall Members Art Show
Annual exhibit showcasing local and regional artists.
Tuesdays - Sundays, Sep. 5 - 28, 2025 | 12:00 p.m. - 4:00 p.m.
Fall Members Art Show
(904) 824-2310
At the corner of Cadiz & Marine.
22 Marine Street
St. Augustine, FL 32084
View Google Map
Share This
+1 more
The St. Augustine Art Association presents the annual Fall Members Show beginning on Friday, September 5, 2025, and running until Sunday, September 28, 2025. This juried exhibit presents the works of St. Augustine Art Association members, welcoming all subjects and media such as oil on canvas, sculpture, and fiber-work. Visitors delight in the diverse range of expressive artwork from local and regional artists. The exhibit is also available for online viewing throughout the month.
A panel of independent jurors handpicks exceptional artists and awards monetary prizes, including the prestigious "Jean Wagner Troemel Best of Show" award. Much of the artwork is available for purchase, and proceeds support the artists and the art programs at the St. Augustine Art Association, an esteemed non-profit arts organization founded in 1924.
Admission:
Free
When:
The exhibit will open on Friday, September 5, 2025, during
First Friday Art Walk
and will remain on display through Sunday, September 28, 2025. Gallery hours are 12:00 to 4:00 p.m. Tuesday through Sunday. The gallery is closed on Mondays.
Where:
The
St. Augustine Art Association
is located at 22 Marine St. in downtown St. Augustine, Florida 32084.
Fall Members Art Show
(904) 824-2310
At the corner of Cadiz & Marine.
22 Marine Street
St. Augustine, FL 32084

St. Augustine Film Society: Amélie
A French woman seeks love and changes the lives of others.
Sunday, Sep. 7, 2025 | 4:00 p.m. - 8:00 p.m.
St. Augustine Film Society: Amélie
(904) 254-9524
Share This
On Sunday, September 7, 2025, at 4:00 p.m. at the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship, the St. Augustine Film Society is partnering with the Francophone Club to screen the award-winning romantic comedy,
Amélie
(2001).
A whimsical story, written and directed by Jean-Pierre Jeunet, follows a young French woman's journey of self-discovery and finding true love. Amélie tries to make a positive impact on those she cares about most, in hopes of creating her own world where she's in control. Shot in more than 80 Parisian locations, the cinematography and visual style give this work a quirkiness and a comforting appeal that leaves audiences captivated.
Admission:
$10.00 for the public. St. Augustine Film Society members are free.
When:
Sunday, September 7, 2025, at 4:00 p.m. Doors open at 3:30 p.m.
Where:
Unitarian Universalist Fellowship, 2487 A1A South, St. Augustine, Florida 32080.
St. Augustine Film Society: Amélie
(904) 254-9524
2487 A1A South
St.Augustine Beach, FL 32080

Can't-Miss Events
Find the latest and greatest events in the oldest city.
Throughout the year, St. Augustine hosts unforgettable festivals, live music, and cultural celebrations. Whether it’s a nationally recognized music festival, a holiday festivity, or an authentic reenactment, there's always something
BIG
happening in this tiny town. From art exhibits and live theater to historical events and culinary creations, our can't-miss events feature the best of the nation’s oldest city.

CEAM: Department of Visual Arts Faculty Exhibit
Experience the talents of Flagler College's visual arts faculty.
Monday-Saturday, Sep. 5 - Nov. 8, 2025 | Times Vary
CEAM: Department of Visual Arts Faculty Exhibit
48 Sevilla St.
St. Augustine, FL 32084
View Google Map
Share This
The
Crisp-Ellert Art Museum
(CEAM) and
Flagler College
present the Department of Visual Art Faculty Exhibition from September 5 to November 8, 2025. View the artwork Monday through Friday from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., and on Saturdays from 12:00 to 4:00 p.m.
This special exhibit showcases the recent works of the full- and part-time fine art and graphic design faculty. The opening reception, which is free and open to the public, is on Friday, September 5, from 5:00 to 8:00 p.m. as part of the
First Friday Art Walk
. At 6:00 p.m., several of the featured artists lead an informal walk through of the exhibition.
The exhibition features work by artists: Sarah Alexander, Luke Brodersen (and Future Friends), Diana Lodi, Jenna McDonald, Russell Maycumber, Laura Mongiovi, Patrick Moser, Natalie Novak, Sara Pedigo, Bernadette Rivell, Leslie Robison, Jason Schwab, and Chris Smith. The show also introduces new faculty members Samuel Aye-Gboyin, Ida Moraghebati, and Ron Edelen.
On Wednesday, October 29, at 6 p.m., Dr. Stephanie Hohlios, an Assistant Professor of Art History, presents a lecture titled "Art History as Community Engagement." The talk takes place in the Virginia Room of the Ringhaver Student Center at Flagler College, located at 50 Sevilla Street. Dr. Hohlios specializes in modern and contemporary Japanese art, including painting, performance, and community-based projects. Her fieldwork focuses on the former coal mining area of Chikuhō on the island of Kyushu in Japan.
Admission:
Free and open to the public.
When:
The exhibition runs from September 5 to November 8, 2025. The museum's hours are Monday through Friday, 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., and Saturday, 12:00 to 4:00 p.m., while classes are in session.
Where:
The Crisp-Ellert Art Museum (CEAM), 74 King Street in
Historic Downtown
.
CEAM: Department of Visual Arts Faculty Exhibit
48 Sevilla St.
St. Augustine, FL 32084

Historical Events
History is the backbone of St. Augustine and is ever present in many of the local events. Living history takes visitors back in time to imagine what life was like in the colonial days of St. Augustine. Historic re-enactments take place often to re-create the significant events in St. Augustine’s past. Annual re-enactments like the Founder’s Day event in St. Augustine or the Spanish Colonial Grand Muster both commemorate notable events during the Spanish colonial period. It is the history in St. Augustine that ties each visitor and resident together and is common in all of us since St. Augustine’s successful port helped shape the country.

5 Things to Know About Founder's Day
This holiday celebrates the entire story of St. Augustine's founding.
Share This
On September 8, 1565, the city of St. Augustine was first founded, making it the oldest continually occupied settlement in the United States. St. Augustine is an important part of American history, and predates our country's oldest colonies, including Jamestown and Williamsburg. It was established by the Spanish and serves as the oldest, continually occupied European settlement in the continental United States.
Founder's Day, or "Founding Day," is the day that Don Pedro Menéndez de Avilés landed in St. Augustine and claimed the new territory (named
La Florida
) for the Spanish Crown. But how many locals and visitors know the full history of Founder's Day? Visitors and locals can celebrate St. Augustine's history by visiting for
Founder's Day in September
each year.
1. Menéndez started his journey from prison.
Many don't know this, but the story of St. Augustine's founding actually starts with Pedro Menéndez in prison. The soon-to-be founding governor had been arrested by the Casa de Contratacion, which governed trade in the Americas and disapproved of Menéndez's strict adherence to enforcing imperial law. Menéndez saw himself as above the Casa, and refused to partake in any of their backhand dealings. Starting in 1563, Menéndez was arrested and served 20 months in prison for a series of charges. He wrote to King Phillip II, confessing his innocence. King Phillip II allowed him to leave in order to lead the expedition to settle Florida.
2. Menéndez found St. Augustine while searching for his son, Juan.
It was during his time in prison that Menéndez received news that his son, Juan, had shipwrecked near Bermuda in 1561. Although Menéndez showed great enthusiasm at the opportunity to bring Christianity to the Native Americans living in Florida—as well as obliterate the French presence at Fort Caroline—it was the search for his son that initiated his call for release. Menéndez was never able to find his son.
A historic black and white block-print of a ship sailing through stormy seas.
3. St. Augustine was named after the feast day of the saint.
The city is named St. Augustine because land was sighted on the feast day of St. Augustine of Hippo on August 28. A feast day is a day of dedication to a saint according to the Christian calendar of saints, usually on the presumed date of their death. St. Augustine of Hippo was a convert to the Christian faith and early theologian. He originally studied rhetoric and sought to be an orator in Rome, but became disillusioned with a life of excess. His book,
Confessions
, is considered the first autobiography of the Western World, and scenes from his life can be seen depicted in the windows of the
Cathedral Basilica of St. Augustine
.
Two colorful stained glass depictions of scenes from the life of Saint Augustine of Hippo.
4. When Menéndez landed, he celebrated mass with his crew.
How do you thank God when you survive a dangerous expedition across a large body of water, with the possibility of hurricanes, scurvy, and pirates? You offer a mass and thank God for your life, and for the lives of your crew. It's one of the first things Menéndez's crew did when they arrived, and it made St. Augustine an important site in the history of Catholicism in America. Pilgrims continue to visit St. Augustine and the Mission Nombre de Dios to this day to explore the site where Christianity came to America.
The Mission Nombre de Dios
has a cathedral, museum, worship center, and walking trails on their property for those looking to learn about, and experience, the religious past of St. Augustine's history.
5. The city of St. Augustine recreates the first landing every year.
Every year, visitors and locals celebrate
Founder's Day
in St. Augustine by viewing a reenactment of the landing. The landing is put on by Florida Living History, whose members dress in traditional Spanish military garb and arrive at the grounds of the Mission Nombre de Dios on a landing boat. The bishop of the Diocese of St. Augustine leads a mass at the rustic altar, just as the original expedition's chaplain, Fr. Francisco López de Mendoza Grajales, did on September 8, 1565.
A reenactment of Pedro Menéndez's landing in 1565 at the site of what was to become St. Augustine.
Museums and Attractions to Discover More about St. Augustine's History...
Fountain of Youth
: Visit this archeological site to learn more about the earliest Spanish settlements with the Timucua in Florida.
Colonial Quarter
: St. Augustine wasn't always a Spanish settlement; learn about the different countries that have influenced the city.
First Colony Museum
: Located at the Old Government House, this exhibit gives a glimpse into the daily lives of early Spanish settlers.
The Shrine of Our Lady of La Leche at the Mission Nombre de Dios
The Diocese of St. Augustine has a museum, shrine, cathedral, worship center, and gardens on the site.
Alex Pooler

Seasonal Events
Celebrate the season with festive events throughout the year.
Celebrate wintertime by taking the family on a holiday-themed tour of the
Nights of Lights
, meeting Santa Claus, and ringing in the New Year with
Fireworks on the Beach
. In the
spring
, enjoy the Cathedral Festival, Old Town Arts and Crafts Show, and the Easter parade. Summer in St. Augustine offers fewer active events, more time
on the beach
, and a chance to visit our attractions. Watch as fireworks light up the summer sky on the
4th of July
. And don't forget fall—the spookiest season around, thanks to Halloween and all the
ghosts
that live here. The city celebrates every season in style, so there's always something fresh and fun to do.

Nights of Lights

Food Festivals & Events
Foodie fun with culinary heritage events and festivals.
St. Augustine is home to local delicacies such as the datil pepper and Minorcan clam chowder. Celebrate this culinary heritage at food festivals and farm-to-table events around town. Enjoy the eats at the annual Great Chowder Debate and the
Lions Seafood Festival
. And don't forget to stay hydrated St. Augustine style via the
Spanish Wine Festival
and the
St. Augustine Brewers' Fest
. Here, food and drink are celebrated daily, so there's always something local to taste.

Broadway Rave at Cafe Eleven
A high-energy music rave celebrating the most iconic Broadway characters.
Saturday, Sep. 6, 2025 | 8:30 p.m. - 10:30 p.m.
Broadway Rave at Cafe Eleven
(904) 460-9311
Just one short block from the beach.
501 A1A Beach Blvd.
St. Augustine, FL 32080
View Google Map
Share This
Cafe Eleven welcomes Broadway Rave on Saturday, September 6, 2025, at 8:30 p.m. Doors open at 8:00 p.m.
The Broadway Rave celebrates the best in musical theatre. It invites partygoers to dress as their favorite Broadway characters and immerse themselves in an electrifying night of music and dance. Classic Broadway hits are reimagined with fast tempos, heavy basslines, and synthesized beats, creating a unique fusion of theatre and rave culture.
The event also features special appearances by Broadway stars.
Admission is restricted to guests 18 and older, with an additional $5.00 fee for those younger than 21. Smoking is strictly prohibited on the premises.
Admission:
Early bird tickets are $21.98, and general admission tickets are $25.00.
Purchase tickets in advance online
or
at Cafe Eleven on the day of the show.

Saturday, September 6, 2025, at 8:30 p.m. Doors open at 8:00 p.m.

Rally for Recovery
Rev up for behavioral health.
Saturday, Sep. 6, 2025 | 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.
Rally for Recovery
4730 U.S. 1
St. Augustine, FL 32086
View Google Map
Share This
EPIC Behavioral Healthcare presents the 5th Annual Rally for Recovery at the
Classic Car Museum of St. Augustine
on Saturday, September 6, 2025 from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.
This free, family-friendly event features food trucks, music, and local behavioral health organizations providing important information. The event also features inspiring speakers and testimonials, raffle prizes, and activities like memorial rock art and free t-shirt giveaways (while supplies last).

Founders Day Plein Air Paint Out
See how artists transform a blank canvas into a finished landscape.
Friday - Monday, Sep. 5 - 8, 2025 | Times Vary
Founders Day Plein Air Paint Out
(904) 824-2310
This event takes place at various locations throughout town.
Share This
The St. Augustine Art Association hosts the Founder's Day Plein Air Paint Out from Friday, September 5, 2025, to Monday, September 9, 2025, at various locations throughout town.
This free event invites artists to paint en plein air around St. Augustine on Founder's Day weekend. This practice, a French term meaning "in the open air," involves artists painting outdoors directly from the landscape. Artists must be registered and must check in to paint. You can enjoy watching artists throughout town while you're out exploring.
Admission:
Free (Artists must
register online
by September 4, 2025.)
When:
Sunday, September 14, 2025, from 12:00 to 5:00 p.m.
Where:
Various locations throughout town.
About STAAA:
St. Augustine Art Association
serves as a central hub for art exhibitions, education, and community involvement, committed to fostering artistic excellence and honoring the rich cultural heritage of St. Johns County.
For Artists:
Artists must register online.
Find more information.
Painting Locations:
Artists may paint anywhere deemed legal by the city of St. Augustine, as detailed here
. They may also paint at the following locations:
Father Miguel O’Reilly House
garden (on select days, sign-up will be required) and on the exterior grounds of the
Castillo de San Marcos
.
Founders Day Plein Air Paint Out
(904) 824-2310
This event takes place at various locations throughout town.

Amphitheatre Farmers Market
Enjoy fresh local produce, handmade arts and crafts, and live entertainment.
Saturdays | 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.
Amphitheatre Farmers Market
(904) 315-9252
St. Augustine Amphitheatre
1340C A1A South
St. Augustine, FL 32080
View Google Map
Share This
+2 more
On Saturday mornings, from 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., purchase plants, fresh produce, eggs, cheese, prepared foods, and art at the St. Augustine Amphitheatre Farmers Market.
This favorite event for locals and visitors brings a bustling crowd every week as people shop for fresh groceries, gifts, souvenirs, and breakfast or lunch. Vendors line both sides of the corridor between the Amphitheatre front door and the parking lot.
As you near the Front Porch, you'll hear live music from the
Free Rangers
, a jam band with local and visiting amateur and professional musicians. The Free Rangers offer a wide variety of music including bluegrass, folk, and old rock spiced with the occasional original tune. If it's a perfect Saturday morning, take your time shopping, grab food and a drink from one of the vendors, and sit with friends while enjoying the band.
The list of vendors is long, and the foods available include fresh cheese, locally-caught shrimp, guacamole prepared while you wait, and organic produce. Local authors and artists sell their books, greeting cards, jewelry, baby gear, pet gear, soaps, and a whole lot more.
Each Saturday, several food trucks serve their specialties, a few bakeries offer fresh-baked treats as long as supplies last, and the Amphitheatre's bar makes one of the best—and spiciest Bloody Marys.
Admission:
Free
When:
Saturday mornings from 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.
Where:
St. Augustine Amphitheatre
, 1340 A1A South, St. Augustine, Florida 32080.
Extra parking is available at the Elk's Lodge just south of the Amphitheatre.
For more information, including how to be a vendor,
visit here.
(Scroll down on that page for the vendor form.)
Amphitheatre Farmers Market
(904) 315-9252
St. Augustine Amphitheatre
1340C A1A South
St. Augustine, FL 32080

Fort Mose Militia Muster & Training
Experience authentic 18th-century weapons demonstrations.
First Saturday of the month except July | 9:30 a.m. to 11:30 a.m.
Fort Mose Militia Muster & Training
(904) 823-2232
15 Fort Mose Trail
St Augustine, FL 32084
View Google Map
Share This
Fort Mose Historic State Park hosts Militia Muster and Training on the first Saturday of each month — except for July.
The Fort Mose Militia bring the 18th century back to life by practicing their firing drills, and by teaching new members historic weapons use and safety. Park visitors witness the weapons demonstrations, which include musket firings. This unique experience provides great photo opportunities and is a wonderful way to spend a day enjoying a state park.
For more information, visit here.
Admission:
The program itself is free. Admission into the Visitor Center is $2.00 for adults and free for children under six.
When:
The first Saturday of each month (except July) from 9:30 to 11:30 a.m.
Where:
Fort Mose Historic State Park is located at 15 Fort Mose Trail, St. Augustine, Florida 32084.

15 Fort Mose Trail
St Augustine, FL 32084

Guided Exploration Hike
Guests explore the flora and fauna of the Guana Peninsula.
First Saturday of the Month | 9:00 a.m. - 11:00 a.m.
Guided Exploration Hike
(904) 380-8600
505 Guana River Road
Ponte Vedra Beach, FL 32082
View Google Map
Share This
The Guana Tolomato Matanzas National Estuarine Research Reserve (GTMNERR) invites visitors to explore the natural beauty and biodiversity of the Guana Peninsula during a guided hike held on the first Saturday of each month from 9:00 to 11:00 a.m. This informative hike offers a deep dive into the peninsula’s 5,000 years of human history, including how native peoples utilized estuarine resources and the ongoing efforts to preserve these vital ecosystems.
Participants should meet at the GTM Research Reserve’s Trailhead Pavilion, located west of the Guana Dam. Hikers are advised to wear comfortable closed-toe shoes for the hike. The hike is a free event but a $3.00 per vehicle parking fee applies.
For more information please
email Abigail Kuhn
.
Admission:
Free with a $3.00 per vehicle parking fee. Registration for this event is required, so
register now
to reserve your spot.
When:
The first Saturday of every month, from 9:00 to 11:00 a.m.
Where:
Meet at the GTM Research Reserve’s Trailhead Pavilion, located west of the Guana Dam at 505 Guana River Road, Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida 32082.
About GTMNERR:
The Guana Tolomato Matanzas National Estuarine Research Reserve
is a protected stretch of land consisting of wetlands and estuaries on Florida's East Coast that actively works to maintain and help preserve the natural landscape of Florida. The GTMNERR's volunteers and employees are dedicated to the preservation of an unspoiled and undeveloped natural treasure, supporting a vibrant ecosystem and subsystems.
Guided Exploration Hike
(904) 380-8600
505 Guana River Road
Ponte Vedra Beach, FL 32082

Comedy Carousel
Crazy improvised comedy, in constant motion, that changes every week.
Saturdays through October 11 | 8:00 p.m. - 10:00 p.m.
Comedy Carousel
(904) 342-7299
Two blocks from King Street's Carmelo's Pizza.
200 Malaga Street, #7
St. Augustine, FL 32084
View Google Map
Share This
Show all
Third Space Improv
presents Comedy Carousel on Saturdays at 8:00 p.m. through October 11, 2025.
Step right up to the Comedy Carousel—a fast, fun weekly improv show where the laughs are constantly spinning. Third Space Improv's all-start cast take your suggestions and transform them into scenes, games, and characters that twist and turn in all directions. With every spin of the carousel, there's brand-new comedy that's constantly changing—no two rides are ever the same.
The First Spin:
Every game is a new ride on the comedy carousel.
The Next Go-Round:
Stay on the carousel for the whole ride—instead of hopping off after each turn, the story keeps spinning as the characters circle around.
This show is for all ages.
Third Space Improv offers beer, wine, soft drinks, fresh popcorn, and a snack bar in the Laughter Lounge 30 minutes before the show starts.
Admission:
Tickets are $15.00 in advance and $20.00 at the door—
they can be purchased here
.
When:
8:00 - 10:00 p.m. Saturdays through October 11, 2025.
Where:
Third Space Improv, 200 Malaga Street, #7, St. Augustine—two blocks from Historic Downtown.
There is free parking in the lot at Third Space Improv.

Yoga on the Lawn
The Ximenez-Fatio House hosts yoga in the museum's serene lawn.
Every Wednesday & Sunday | 8:30 a.m. - 9:30 a.m.
View Website
(904) 325-1497
Yoga on the Lawn
(904) 325-1497
In the museum's front lawn.
20 Aviles St.
St. Augustine, FL 32084
View Google Map
Share This
The Ximenez-Fatio House Museum hosts Yoga on the Lawn every Wednesday and Sunday from 8:30 to 9:30 a.m.
This vinyasa flow yoga session is suitable for all levels, and each participant should bring a yoga mat or towel and water. Follow along as an instructor from
Pilates Yoga Loft
leads a class on the front lawn of the Ximenez-Fatio House Museum.
Free parking at the museum can be accessed from Cadiz Street.
Admission:
Pre-registration is required and is $15.00 per person. Sign up on the
Mind Body app
or call (904) 325-1497 for more information on special class passes.
When:
Every Wednesday and Sunday from 8:30 to 9:30 a.m. unless no one registers.
Where:
The Ximenez-Fatio House Museum, 20 Aviles Street, St. Augustine, Florida 32084.
NOTE: Some dates may be cancelled due to inclement weather. Credits will be given to students for future classes—refunds are not offered.

Event Venues
Celebrate a special event in a local venue of your choosing.
Most of St. Augustine's
hotels
have meeting rooms as do many of the restaurants. There are also fish camps, state or county
park
pavilions, studios, theatres, and even a miniature golf course party area. Many private local clubs, such as the
St. Augustine Yacht Club
, rent space and provide chairs, tables, and even meals. Some venues allow guests to hire their own
caterer
, bring their own food, or even rent a
food truck
or three to feed the crowd. In addition to traditional
wedding
and event spaces, St. Augustine offers fun and funky out-of-the-box spaces too.

Weekend Cannon Firing
Be a part of history at the Castillo de San Marcos every weekend.
Saturdays and Sundays | 10:30 & 11:30 a.m., and 1:30, 2:30, & 3:30 p.m.
Weekend Cannon Firing
(904) 829-6506
Directly on the Bayfront
1 South Castillo Dr.
St. Augustine, FL 32084
View Google Map
Share This
Show all
Experience a little piece of history at the
Castillo de San Marcos
(the fort in downtown St. Augustine). On most Saturdays and Sundays, reenactors in period dress and living historians perform weapons demonstrations and fire the cannons at the Castillo.
See what it was like for the Spanish colonial settlers who used to live there. Under times of siege or other emergencies, all people in the settlement were ordered inside the fort for protection, and the cannons were aimed and fired if needed.
Park rangers and living historians give a detailed history of the fort and its previous residents. Look for the marks and drawings British and Spanish soldiers left on the soft coquina walls.
Admission:
Admission to the Castillo is $15.00 per adult. Children 15 and younger are free if they are accompanied by an adult. Tickets are valid for seven consecutive days. The Golden Access and Age Passports, the Castillo Annual Pass, and the Interagency Access, Annual, Military, and Senior Passes are honored for free admission as explained on the terms specified on the card.
The cannon firing can be seen from outside the Castillo, although the description cannot be heard except by those standing near the gundeck.
When:
Cannons are fired from the gundeck on most Saturdays and Sundays throughout the year,
weather and staffing permitting
, at 10:30 and 11:30 a.m. and at 1:30, 2:30, and 3:30 p.m. The fort is closed on Thanksgiving and Christmas.
Where:
Castillo de San Marcos, on the bayfront at 1 South Castillo Drive, St. Augustine, Florida.
Parking
is available in the parking lot in front of the Castillo and can be paid with credit and debit cards at the automated stations. Parking is also available along the street and in the
parking garage
about a block from the fort.
From the National Park Service's FAQ page:
The crew most often fires the cannons. (It's more fun.) If there aren't enough trained volunteers, they fire muskets.
Everything takes place on the gundeck, the upper level of the Castillo, which is accessible only by stairs. You can also see and hear the cannons outside the fort, in an area that has a ramp for access.
The cannons are loud, like fireworks, and the muskets sound like modern guns. The
National Park Service has an accessibility page
to help you make decisions for you and your family.
The National Park Service cancels cannon and musket demonstrations during thunderstorms or extremely hot days. If there aren't enough staff and crew on a particular day, they may have to cancel. You can prevent that by becoming an active volunteer.
Weekend Cannon Firing
(904) 829-6506
Directly on the Bayfront
1 South Castillo Dr.
St. Augustine, FL 32084

Yoga in the Garden
The Lightner Museum hosts yoga in the Radzinski Family Garden.
Third Saturdays | 8:30 a.m. - 9:30 a.m.
View Website
Yoga in the Garden
In the Radzinski Family Garden.
75 King Street
St. Augustine, FL 32084
View Google Map
Share This
Show all
The Lightner Museum hosts Yoga In the Garden on the third Saturday of each month from 8:30 to 9:30 a.m.
This yoga session is suitable for all, and each participant should bring a yoga mat or towel and water. An instructor from
Serenity Yoga
leads the session on the lawn of the Radzinski Family Garden, on the south end of the building. This event recalls the days of Henry Flagler's Alcazar Hotel and its well-known spa facilities.
If the grass is wet, the class will be moved to the sidewalk next to the lawn.
Admission:
This is a donation-based event, and registration is not required.
When:
On the third Saturday of each month, from 8:30 to 9:30 a.m.
Where:
The Radzinski Family Garden is behind the Lightner Museum at 75 King Street, St. Augustine.
NOTE:
Some dates may be rescheduled due to inclement weather.

In the Radzinski Family Garden.
75 King Street
St. Augustine, FL 32084
